descriptionSet.description: A colonial station building, incorporating certain mughal architectural elements, with several empty railtracks can be seen.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: A colonial station building, incorporating certain mughal architectural elements, with several empty railtracks can be seen. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: This image offers a closer view of another colonial institution and that ultimate symbol of colonial progress: the railways. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: With its minarets and arched windows, this railway station, now in Pakistan, expresses through architecture how the British saw themselves as inheritors of Mughal rule, rather than conquerors and thus the legitimate rulers of the Indian subcontinent. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)
related literature: Mukherjee, Hena 1994. "The early history of the east Indian Railway". Calcutta: KLM. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-19. (gs)
